item.content:encoded:
Twitter has threatened legal action against Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, over its new social media platform, Threads.

The threat was made in a letter sent by Twitter lawyer Alex Spiro to Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg. The news was first reported from a report published by news website Semaphore.

Meta launched ‘Threads’ last Wednesday. It is being considered as a rival to Twitter.

In a letter to Zuckerberg, lawyer Alex Spiro alleged that Meta hired former Twitter employees. Those employees were privy to and still have access to Twitter’s commercial and highly confidential information.

Spiro also wrote, ‘Twitter authorities want to strictly enforce intellectual property rights and demand that Meta take immediate action to stop the use of Twitter’s commercially confidential information or any other confidential information.

Reuters contacted Meta and Spiro for comment. However, there was no immediate response.

A source familiar with the letter confirmed the news to Reuters. Reuters also reached out to Spiro for comment, but did not receive a response.

Meta spokesperson Andy Stone said in a post on Threads that no member of the Threads engineering team is a former Twitter employee. Nothing like that happened here.

A former senior Twitter employee told Reuters he was not aware of any former Twitter employees working on Threads.

Meanwhile, Twitter owner Elon Musk said competition is good, but cheating is not.

It should be noted that the activities of Threads are being conducted under the control of Instagram, a popular social media for sharing pictures and videos. As a result, it can be accessed using the Instagram account. In addition to sending messages, links, images, GIFs and videos can also be sent.
